Laurence Olivier Awards History

The Observance of Laurence Olivier Awards is dedicated to honouring outstanding achievements in British theatre. Recognised as some of the most prestigious accolades in the performing arts, these illustrious awards celebrate the exceptional talent and outstanding productions across various categories, including plays, musicals, dance, opera and affiliate productions. Directors, actors, playwrights, composers, and designers are among the many professionals recognised, demonstrating the wide-ranging and essential roles that contribute to the thriving theatre scene in the United Kingdom.

Established in 1976, the Laurence Olivier Awards were named in honour of the acclaimed British actor, director, and producer, Sir Laurence Olivier. Steeped in a rich history of theatre, the awards bear a special significance for British talent and stagecraft, garnering immense respect not only in the UK but among the international performing arts community. For people in the United Kingdom, the Observance of Laurence Olivier Awards represents a momentous occasion to acknowledge and appreciate the significant cultural contribution that theatre provides to the nation, reflecting its artistic heritage and creative spirit.

During the Observance in the United Kingdom, audiences are treated to a star-studded awards ceremony, featuring performances from nominated shows, as well as appearances and speeches by renowned guests and industry figures. Hosted by The Society of London Theatre, the ceremony typically takes place in April, each year. The event is often televised or streamed online, allowing theatre enthusiasts all over the country to participate in the observance.

Laurence Olivier Awards Facts

In 2023, the Best Actress award went to Jodie Comer for her performance in Prima Facie at the Harold Pinter Theatre. The Best Actor award went to Paul Mescal for his performance in A Streetcar Named Desire at the Almeida Theatre.

The Olivier Award winners are chosen by four panels each overseen by the Society of London Theatre (SOLT). Professional panellists are chosen for their knowledge in the selected ï¬eld. Each panel is made up of various members including journalists, casting directors, arts administrators and publishers all speciï¬cally chosen for their passion for London theatre.

The original awards were commissioned blue Wedgewood urns. They were changed in 1984, when the award show was renamed the Laurance Olivier Awards. The new award was changed from blue urns to bronze statues of a young Laurence Olivier portrayed as Henry V.

The musical Hamilton holds the record for most Olivier Award nominations, receiving 13 nominations in 2018.

The Laurence Olivier Awards have a strong influence on West End attendance; winning an award can boost ticket sales and extend the life of a production.
